claim: People smoke more on average in the United States than in Russia.

supporting.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the United States has a higher adult smoking prevalence rate than Russia as of recent data.

attacks.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), the United States has a higher adult smoking prevalence rate than Russia as of recent data.
The WHO data may not account for differences in data collection methodologies between the United States and Russia, potentially skewing the comparison.
The WHO standardizes data collection protocols across countries to ensure comparability, minimizing methodological discrepancies.
Cultural differences in self-reporting smoking habits could lead to underreporting in Russia, making the prevalence appear lower than it is.
Studies have shown that self-reporting biases in smoking prevalence are minimal when validated with biochemical measures, which the WHO incorporates.

supporting.text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that cigarette consumption per capita is higher in the United States than in Russia.

attacks.text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that cigarette consumption per capita is higher in the United States than in Russia.
The CDC data may not account for unregulated tobacco markets or informal cigarette sales, which are more prevalent in Russia.
Independent studies have corroborated CDC findings by cross-referencing with WHO and Russian health ministry data, showing consistency in per capita consumption metrics.
Cultural differences in smoking behavior, such as higher rates of pipe or cigar use in Russia, may skew per capita comparisons if only cigarettes are measured.
The CDC explicitly adjusts for non-cigarette tobacco products in its per capita estimates, as noted in its methodology documentation.

supporting.text: Government tobacco taxation policies in Russia have led to reduced smoking rates compared to the United States.

attacks.text: Government tobacco taxation policies in Russia have led to reduced smoking rates compared to the United States.
Cultural attitudes towards smoking in Russia remain more permissive than in the United States, leading to higher actual smoking rates despite taxation policies.
Studies show that taxation policies in Russia have indeed reduced smoking prevalence significantly over the past decade, more so than in the U.S.
The effectiveness of tobacco taxation in Russia is undermined by widespread black market cigarette sales, which are not reflected in official statistics.
Enforcement against black market tobacco sales has improved in Russia, reducing the gap between official and actual smoking rates.

supporting.text: Public health campaigns in Russia have been more aggressive in reducing smoking prevalence than those in the United States.

attacks.text: Public health campaigns in Russia have been more aggressive in reducing smoking prevalence than those in the United States.
The effectiveness of public health campaigns does not necessarily correlate with actual smoking rates due to cultural and economic factors.
Cultural acceptance of smoking in Russia remains high despite public health campaigns, leading to sustained smoking rates.
Smoking prevalence data shows that the United States has higher smoking rates than Russia, regardless of public health efforts.
Recent studies indicate that smoking rates in Russia have declined significantly due to strict tobacco control policies.

supporting.text: Statistical data from the World Bank indicates that the average number of cigarettes smoked per adult annually is higher in the United States than in Russia.

attacks.text: Statistical data from the World Bank indicates that the average number of cigarettes smoked per adult annually is higher in the United States than in Russia.
The World Bank data may not account for informal or black-market cigarette sales, which are more prevalent in Russia and could significantly underreport actual smoking rates.
Even with informal sales, the World Bank methodology includes estimates for unrecorded consumption, making its figures reliable for cross-country comparisons.
Cultural differences in smoking behavior (e.g., social vs. solitary smoking) may lead to undercounting in Russia where shared cigarettes are common.
Standardized surveys used by the World Bank explicitly track individual consumption, minimizing cultural bias in data collection.
